gpt_res: A case study has shown that home diagnosis and monitoring of COVID-19 is possible using portable ultrasound, pulse oximetry, and antibody testing. The patient, a healthy emergency physician, was able to self-isolate for four weeks and had an uneventful recovery. Her diagnosis was confirmed with a positive IgG antibody test after three weeks. The use of these tools in a home setting could potentially reduce the risk of infection for other patients and healthcare providers, limit the use of hospital resources, and enable better social distancing and isolation practices. However, these resources may not be available to all patients or in many acute care settings.

The COVID-19 pandemic has significantly impacted India, with thousands of people getting infected daily. A study used daily statistics of people affected by the disease to predict future trends in active cases in Odisha and India. The data was collected from the WHO daily statistics and a regression model was applied to visualize the trend of the affected cases. The study found a strong prediction model to forecast the next coming days active cases. Using this model, it predicted 52,290 active cases by 15th August in India and 9,358 active cases in Odisha if the situation continues as is. The models showed remarkable accuracy in COVID-19 recognition.

The study suggests that the drug Celebrex may be effective in treating COVID-19. Researchers found that COVID-19 patients had significantly higher levels of prostaglandins E2 (PGE2) in their urine, which they believe is a key factor in the disease. In an experiment involving 44 COVID-19 patients, those given Celebrex showed a reduction in PGE2 levels and improved recovery rates. The remission rate was 100% for those treated with a full dose, 82% for those with a half dose, and 57% for the control group.

The paper discusses the role of marketing in promoting socially responsible consumption during crises. It introduces the concept of consumer-centric socially responsible consumption (CCSRC), which expands the current focus on environmental preservation to include consumers' responsibility to protect the health and well-being of others. The paper proposes a conceptual framework that uses social contract theory, contagion theory, and tragedy of the commons literature to show how firms can adapt their social contracts in response to changing crowd dynamics. It suggests that marketing can use social contracts to promote a consumer-centric approach to socially responsible consumption during crises. The paper also discusses the growing trend of socially responsible consumption and its impact on consumer behavior and purchase decisions.

Two trials were conducted in Argentina to assess the effectiveness of an inactivated oil-adjuvanted rotavirus vaccine in beef herds. The first, a small-scale trial, involved 21 pregnant cows and found a significant increase in neutralizing antibody titres in vaccinated cows compared to unvaccinated controls. The second, a large-scale field trial, involved 4066 vaccinated pregnant cows across 17 beef herds. The results showed a significant reduction in morbidity and mortality in 16 of the 17 herds tested, indicating the vaccine's effectiveness. The vaccine also proved effective in farms where other enteropathogens such as cryptosporidium and coronaviruses were present, along with rotavirus.

Most young children with fever and no clear source of infection usually have self-limiting viral infections that resolve without treatment. However, a small percentage may have a bacterial infection that could develop into bacteremia or meningitis. Studies have not yet clearly identified which febrile children may have a serious infection. Parents are often more willing than doctors to risk serious outcomes to avoid the short-term effects of invasive tests and treatments. The best approach to treating a febrile child involves estimating risks, careful clinical evaluation and follow-up, and judicious use of diagnostic tests. The microbes causing fever in children vary with age, season, and symptoms. The most common causes of serious bacterial infection in children under 3 months are shown in Table 14.1. Vaccines reduce the risk of serious bacterial infection. In children between 3 and 35 months, most bacterial infections with no clear source are caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis, or Salmonella spp. infection.

Cold environments can cause a variety of conditions, including primary acrocyanosis, a rare peripheral vascular disorder characterized by painless, symmetrical discoloration of the distal appendages that persists after cold exposure. This condition can often be missed, leading to misdiagnosis and mismanagement. A case study of a 24-year-old female who presented with peripheral cyanosis after cold exposure was eventually diagnosed with primary acrocyanosis. The prognosis for this condition is generally good compared to other acrosyndromes and can be managed conservatively with lifestyle modifications and potential follow-up with Rheumatology once secondary causes have been ruled out.

Healthcare-associated infections (HAI) are those acquired or developed as a result of healthcare. The American Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) defines them as any clinical condition, localized or systemic, resulting from an adverse reaction due to the presence of one or more infectious agents or their toxins, with no evidence that it was present or in the incubation phase at the time of hospital admission. Traditionally, they have been called nosocomial or hospital-acquired infections. Today, they remain the most common complication in hospitalized patients. Between 5-10% of all patients admitted to hospitals will develop one or more infections as a result of their admission or the various diagnostic-therapeutic procedures received. This means that in the US, approximately 2 million patients each year will acquire an infection, of which 90,000 will die as a direct result, with an estimated additional cost of $35.7 to $45 billion per year. In Spain, data from the EPINE Project (Study of the Prevalence of Nosocomial Infections in Spain) confirms these estimates, with the prevalence of nosocomial infection around 8% in the last 4 years. These figures vary depending on the type of hospital, being higher in tertiary or university hospitals (over 500 beds) due to the severity of the underlying disease of the admitted patients and the greater complexity of the diagnostic and therapeutic techniques used. Intensive Care Units (ICU), with prevalences between 30 and 40%, are the areas with the highest infection rates.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a disproportionate impact on minority unemployment in the United States, according to a study. In the first month after social distancing measures were implemented, unemployment rose to 14.5%, or 24.4% when corrected for potential data misclassification. Unemployment among African-Americans rose to 16.6% in April 2020, less than expected based on previous recessions, while Latinx unemployment rose to 18.2%, the highest among major groups. The racial gap in unemployment expanded as white unemployment declined but remained largely stagnant for blacks. The gap between white and Latinx unemployment remained in May and June. The study also found that an unfavorable occupational distribution and lower average skills levels put these groups at higher risk of job losses.

Virtual screening (VS) is a widely used method in the pharmaceutical industry for identifying lead structures for drug development. It involves using computer programs to evaluate large libraries of compounds, with the aim of finding novel chemical structures that yield unique pharmacological profiles. The success of a virtual screen is defined by finding new scaffolds rather than many hits. VS has gained increased attention due to the rise in available datasets and successful screening studies. It can aid in the rapid identification of novel ligands when integrated with high throughput screening. VS methods are often divided into structure-based VS and ligand-based VS. The use of machine learning techniques for VS is also gaining interest.

The paper introduces a new mathematical model for the propagation of the SARS-CoV-2 virus, which includes all possible preventative actions and aids in the recovery of infected individuals. The model's equilibrium and stability properties are discussed, and the effects of different control actions on the spread of the epidemic are analyzed. The results are presented through numerical evaluations, showing the impact on different population groups. Elsevier has created a COVID-19 resource center, which hosts all its COVID-19-related research, and has granted permission for its free use for as long as the resource center remains active.
You didn't provide any text to summarize. Please provide the text you want summarized.

The authors discuss the potential benefits of using propofol, a sedative agent, in treating patients with COVID-19. They highlight its anti-inflammatory and antithrombotic effects, as well as its ability to attenuate angiotensin-II-induced endothelial dysfunction. Two case studies are presented where propofol was used as a first-line sedative agent. In both cases, patients were successfully weaned from the ventilator and showed improved C-reactive protein (CRP) levels, indicating reduced inflammation. However, the authors note that it remains unclear whether propofol directly contributed to the improvement of lung conditions. They also note that the antithrombotic effects of propofol were not clearly observed in these cases.

The study investigates two proteins encoded by the smallest genomic segments of the infectious salmon anaemia virus (ISAV). The proteins, s7ORF1 and s8ORF2, are involved in modulating the type I interferon (IFN) response. The s7ORF1 protein is non-structural and localises mainly to the cytoplasmic perinuclear area, while the s8ORF2 protein is a structural component of the viral particle and has a predominantly nuclear localisation. Both proteins independently down-regulate the type I IFN promoter activity, suggesting that ISAV counteracts the type I IFN response through the action of at least two of its gene products.

The study evaluated 23 patients with persistent COVID-19 olfactory dysfunction, or loss of smell, over a period of 1-4 months. The patients' olfactory functions were assessed using the Sniffin’ Sticks Test, and their olfactory bulb volumes and sulcus depth were measured using MRI. The study excluded pediatric and pregnant patients, and those with a history of head trauma, preexisting smell and taste alterations, allergic rhinitis and chronic rhinosinusitis. The study found that patients had persistent stable or mildly improved olfactory dysfunction after the resolution of other COVID-19 related symptoms.

The study aimed to investigate if oxygen could be delivered to a large animal with induced hypoxia by perfusing the abdomen with oxygenated neat perfluorocarbon. The experiment was conducted on six pigs, three of which were perfused with oxygenated perfluorocarbon and three with oxygenated saline. The results showed a significant increase in arterial oxygen saturation from 82.2% to 91.4% in the animals perfused with oxygenated perfluorocarbon. The study concluded that the peritoneal surface could serve as a supplemental "artificial lung" when perfused with oxygenated perfluorocarbon, potentially aiding in the supportive care of patients suffering from hypoxia due to reversible lung injury.

Since 1994, there have been eight major outbreaks caused by seven different bat-borne viruses. Shi Zhengli, a research scientist at the Wuhan Institute of Virology, has been studying these viruses, particularly SARS, and has found dozens of SARS-like coronaviruses that could infect humans. This work allowed her team to quickly identify the virus causing Covid-19. Shi advocates for a proactive approach to dealing with these viruses, stating "We must find them before they find us." This contrasts with the usual defensive strategy, which is reactive and often waits for evidence of human-to-human spread before taking action. The article suggests that due to increasing human interaction with wild animals and their habitats, the species barrier is becoming thinner, providing more opportunities for viruses to jump to humans. The authors argue for a focus on prevention and control of the coronavirus family due to its devastating impact.

The article discusses the evolution of tourism in protected areas of China. It highlights the role of the conservation sector in developing nature-based tourism through the establishment and maintenance of protected areas. The International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) classifies protected areas into seven categories based on management objectives. Tourism and recreation are primary management objectives for some of these categories. The article also notes that while tourism in protected areas has the potential to support biodiversity conservation and reduce poverty, it often leads to ecological degradation and provides little benefit to local communities. Understanding the evolution of a tourism destination and the causes and consequences of changing supply and demand elements is crucial for sustainable tourism development.

Despite efforts to eliminate health disparities in the U.S., African American men still have some of the highest disease and mortality rates globally. This study focuses on the role of microRNAs (miRNAs) in the progression of prostate cancer, particularly in African American men. The research explores how miRNAs contribute to aggressive prostate cancer, including the role of androgen receptors and growth factors. It also discusses how genetic variations in African American men, such as increased activity of the enzyme 5- α -reductase and fewer G and GGC repeats in the androgen receptor gene, may lead to increased risk and sensitivity to prostate cancer.

The study conducted molecular characterization of infectious bronchitis viruses (IBVs) isolated from chickens in Russia between 1998 and 2002. Over 250 field samples were tested, and 91 IBV isolates were characterized. The majority of isolates showed a close sequence relationship with strains of the Massachusetts genotype, which has been circulating in Russia since the early 1970s. Other Russian IBVs showed similarity to strains of European genotypes. The study also found six novel Russian genotypes, often correlating with their geographic location. The data demonstrated the high genetic diversity of IBV isolates circulating in Russia.

Sunjaya and Jenkins argue for the universal use of face masks, particularly home-made cloth masks, to combat Covid-19. They note that the effectiveness of these masks depends on the type of cloth and the number of layers used. The authors tested 49 different fabrics for their filtration capacity and breathability, finding that two-layered nonwoven and jersey knit filtered over 70% of 3 μm particles. Cotton plain weave was the most effective for filtering smaller particles. They also tested 38 more complex textiles, with seven able to filter over 90% of 3 μm particles while maintaining good breathability.

The global spread of infectious diseases like COVID-19 necessitates mass vaccination, which requires significant investment and a coalition of stakeholders for research, development, manufacturing, and administration. While recent efforts have focused on expediting the research and development phase, less attention has been paid to modernizing other aspects of the vaccine process. The authors conducted two studies on vaccine manufacturing and administration capabilities in the context of infectious disease emergencies. They found that there are currently about 60 vaccine candidates in the preclinical development stage for COVID-19. However, concerns have been raised about the time to clinical trial start-up, adequate manufacturing scale-up, regulatory concerns, and sufficient funding. The authors also noted that innovation for vaccine manufacturing has been slow due to limited commercial markets and technical challenges.

Rotavirus diarrhea is a significant cause of infantile gastroenteritis globally, causing 25-30% of all deaths in children under five in developing countries. The virus also poses a public health issue in developed countries, leading to substantial hospitalizations among children and the elderly. This review focuses on the effects of Rotavirus on intestinal epithelial transport and the pathophysiological mechanisms that cause intestinal fluid secretion. Rotavirus, a member of the Reoviridae family, is the leading cause of infantile gastroenteritis worldwide and is responsible for approximately 20% of diarrhea-associated deaths in children under five. The virus infects the mature enterocytes in the mid and upper part of the villi.

The Virus Pathogen Resource (ViPR) and Influenza Research Database (IRD) have developed a tool called meta-CATS, which performs statistical comparative analyses of nucleotide and amino acid sequence data to identify correlations between sequence variations and virus attributes. This tool can help identify genotype-phenotype correlations for the development of improved vaccines, diagnostics, and therapeutics. The tool has been used to identify sequence biomarkers associated with dengue viruses isolated from different hemispheres, and to identify variations in the NS1 protein that are unique to each of the 4 dengue serotypes. The tool is freely available to virology researchers.

A study examining the severity of COVID-19 in Japanese patients found that older age, hypertension, diabetes, low serum albumin, high neutrophil-to-lymphocyte ratio, and C-reactive protein were associated with more severe illness. The study analyzed data from 61 patients, including 58 Japanese and three East Asians, admitted to a hospital between February and April 2020. The researchers found that patients with severe or critical illness were significantly older and more likely to have hypertension or diabetes than those with moderate or mild illness. They also had lower serum albumin levels and higher neutrophil-to-lymphocyte ratios and C-reactive protein levels.

Bats are the natural carriers of the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV) that caused the SARS outbreak in humans in 2002-2003. The genetic diversity of SARS-related coronaviruses (SARSr-CoVs) found in bats is discussed, as well as the bat origin of human SARS. The geographical structure of the virus is also analyzed to better understand the evolution of bat SARSr-CoVs. The major difference between SARS-CoV and SARSr-CoV genomes is in the non-structural protein 3 (nsp3), ORF3, S and ORF8, with the S gene and ORF8 being the most variable. The S gene codes for the spike protein, which is divided into two subunits responsible for receptor binding and cellular membrane fusion. The ORF8 was highly variable during the SARS epidemic in China.

In situ hybridization (ISH) is a technique used to detect nucleic acids in cells, contributing to the understanding of the replication cycle of various hepatitis viruses. ISH has also been used to track the replication of cytomegalovirus within transplanted livers. While ISH is a powerful tool for molecular biologists, its clinical significance in diagnosing and predicting the course of human hepatitis virus infections is still being evaluated. The technique can be used to study viruses that infect and replicate within human liver tissue, potentially providing useful information for clinicians.

A study conducted by the Chaplin School of Hospitality & Tourism Management at Florida International University used an Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average with Intervention analysis technique to examine the impact of the 2008 recession on the hotel and casino hotel segments. The study found that casino hotel firms were affected at the beginning of the recession, while hotel firms and S&P 500 firms were not affected until nine months later. The study also compared the average financial ratios between the two hotel segments to reveal changes in financial structures through the recession. The findings may help industry practitioners and investors prepare for future economic downturns.

Jacob Copeman's Veins of Devotion explores the sociopolitical dynamics of human tissue exchange, focusing on voluntary blood donation campaigns in North India. The book examines the concept of "virtuous utility", which describes the relationship between utilitarian and symbolic reasoning in these campaigns. Copeman argues that blood donation is often presented as a sign of modernity and moral superiority, serving various social, political, and religious agendas. The book also discusses the changing meanings of blood and kinship in India, noting that voluntary blood donation has expanded the traditional boundaries of kinship.

News of a tragedy at the Hajj in Mecca revealed that over 700 pilgrims had died, with some governments suggesting the figure was over 1,000, with a further 900 or more injured. This is described as the worst fatal incident at the Hajj in the past 25 years. Every year, an estimated 3 million Muslim pilgrims converge on Mecca and the surrounding areas. The Saudi Government oversees arrangements to ensure the safety of the pilgrims and will be conducting an investigation into this tragic incident during this 2015 Hajj. Public health threats are commonly dealt with during Hajj, including heat-related illness and the prevention of the spread of many communicable diseases.

The article "Media risk campaigning in the UK: from mobile phones to ‘Baby P’" by Adam Burgess discusses the rise of risk campaigning in British media since the late 1990s. The author notes that this trend began with issues such as mobile phones, genetically modified organisms, and the campaign to expose sex offenders, and has since become normalized and generalized. The article suggests that the success and generalization of these campaigns is due to increasing government responsiveness and accommodation. The author also discusses the role of newspapers in framing risk controversies and the influence of media on public perception of risk.

Protein-protein docking is a complex computational problem in functional genomics, especially when proteins undergo conformational changes upon binding. The main challenge is to create a scoring function that can tolerate these changes and distinguish between near-native and misdocked conformations. Using a linear programming technique, researchers derived protein docking potentials (PDPs) that meet this requirement. The PDPs were tested on a set of 63 nonredundant complexes, generating 400,000 potential docked complexes for each one. The PDPs were able to identify correctly docked structures among the top-ranking decoys in 59 out of 63 cases. The PDPs also revealed biologically meaningful features that distinguish docking potentials from folding potentials. This research is significant as protein-protein interactions provide a framework for cellular activities, and many complexes are too transient for experimental characterization.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is the most common demyelinating disease of the central nervous system, affecting around 1.1 million people globally. It is believed to be caused by an autoimmune response mediated by T-cells. The disease typically begins between the ages of 20 and 40, and affects women more frequently than men. Symptoms can include limb weakness, impaired motor function, sensory symptoms, visual symptoms, and cognitive impairment, among others. The progression of the disease is unpredictable, but can be classified into several distinct clinical courses, including relapsing-remitting MS, secondary chronic progressive MS, and primary chronic progressive MS. Two less common forms are the Marburg variant and benign MS. The cause of MS is unknown, but it is thought that genetic, immunological, and environmental factors all contribute to susceptibility.

A study conducted in Hong Kong has found that 12.3% of male participants had engaged in binge drinking in the three months prior to the survey. The study also found that age and marital status were significantly associated with binge drinking behaviors. The research aimed to investigate the prevalence of binge drinking among Chinese men and the associations between masculine role discrepancy (the perception of being less masculine than the typical man) and binge drinking via discrepancy stress (the strain caused by perceived masculine role discrepancy). The study found that discrepancy stress was positively associated with binge drinking and positively mediated the relationship between masculine role discrepancy and binge drinking. However, a negative direct association was found between masculine role discrepancy and binge drinking. The study contributes to an understanding of the potential health impact of gender role-related issues and determinants of drinking problems.

A study has found that EU funds do not directly influence citizens' support for the European Union. Instead, the funds only mitigate Euroscepticism when they are associated with tangible improvements in local labour market conditions. The research used the Brexit referendum in the UK to test the impact of one of the largest expenditure items in the EU budget, the EU Structural Funds, on electoral support for the EU. The findings suggest that while money cannot buy support for the EU, its ability to generate new local opportunities can.

The article discusses the role of TGF-β signalling in prostate tumourigenesis and immunity. TGF-β is a cytokine that regulates multiple cellular functions and is important for normal prostate development and prostate tumourigenesis. The article covers the interactions of TGF-β-mediated signalling with maintaining prostate health, its role in prostate tumourigenesis and prostate tumour immune evasion. It also discusses how a breakdown in these interactions may influence disease progression. The authors suggest that TGF-β signalling in prostate cancer is a valid target for treatment, but understanding all aspects of the TGF-β-signalling nexus is crucial for effective therapy.
You didn't provide any text to summarize. Please provide the text you want summarized.

The paper explores the concept of freedom in flexible education, questioning who it benefits and how. It argues that while flexible education is often seen as liberating, allowing learners to study at their own pace and in their own way, the institutional and economic factors that influence this type of education are often overlooked. The paper suggests that flexible education can actually limit certain freedoms, serving as a tool of governmentality that regulates subjectivity. It calls for a reevaluation of the concept of freedom in order to make flexible education more beneficial for learners. The paper also highlights that the concept of flexibility in education often favors an idealized version of the learner, ignoring structural forces that may limit access to this type of education.

Since January 2020, Elsevier has established a COVID-19 resource centre offering free information in English and Mandarin about the novel coronavirus. The resource centre is hosted on Elsevier Connect, the company's public news and information website. Elsevier has granted permission for all its COVID-19-related research available on the resource centre to be freely accessible in PubMed Central and other publicly funded repositories, such as the WHO COVID database. This permission is granted for free for as long as the COVID-19 resource centre remains active. The text also discusses the impact of stroke on public health, particularly in China, and the risk factors of pneumonia in stroke patients during rehabilitation.

The novel coronavirus has necessitated significant adjustments in patient care, particularly impacting cancer patients due to various restrictions. Despite mandates, surgical care was still provided, albeit reduced, during the pandemic. Changes in scheduling, resource allocation, and a concerted institutional effort were required to safely perform surgeries without endangering staff, healthcare providers, and other patients. The cover image is based on an article about the application of a chimeric ALT perforator flap with vastus lateralis muscle mass in the reconstruction of defects after radical resection of a buccal carcinoma.

Since January 2020, Elsevier has established a COVID-19 resource centre offering free information in English and Mandarin about the novel coronavirus. The resource centre is hosted on Elsevier Connect, the company's public news and information website. Elsevier has granted permission for all its COVID-19-related research available on the resource centre to be immediately accessible in PubMed Central and other publicly funded repositories, such as the WHO COVID database. This permission is granted for free for as long as the COVID-19 resource centre remains active. The text also discusses the role of nanotechnology in photocatalysis and the global issues of pollution and energy crises. It suggests that the photocatalytic technique could provide some solutions to these problems.

The text discusses a study on the changes in proteolytic and inhibitory activity in the medium from conA-activated cultures. These changes were not directly associated with actively replicating cells, but occurred when lymphocytes were transitioning from a quiescent state to a more metabolically active state in preparation for division. The study also suggests that the activated proteases and/or protease inhibitors were lymphocyte-derived products. However, it remains unclear whether the alterations in proteolytic activity in the conA medium are a by-product of the activation processes or if the secreted substances themselves play a role in activation. The text also describes methods of isolating and collecting germ cells from mouse embryos, including mechanical collection and collagenase treatment.

The text discusses a study on the impact of ACEIs and ARBs drugs on COVID-19 patients. The study found no increased risk of mortality or severe illness in patients using these drugs compared to nonusers. It also suggests that in patients with hypertension, the use of these drugs might be associated with reduced mortality. However, these findings need to be confirmed in prospective randomized controlled trials. It remains unclear whether the continuation or withdrawal of these drugs during hospitalization influences outcomes in COVID-19 patients.

The article discusses the results of a 2003 survey conducted by Dr. Robert Lieb and Brooks A. Bentz, which sought the perspectives of CEOs from 20 of the largest third-party logistics (3PL) providers in the U.S. on the current status and future prospects of the industry. Despite signs of economic improvement, the 3PL industry faced challenges such as a soft economy, increased competition, and customer demands for improved services at lower costs. The survey also explored issues such as the impact of the economic slowdown on the industry, growing customer selectivity, the industry's expansion into China, and future revenue growth rates. The findings are intended to provide insights for both users and providers of 3PL services.

Researchers have used a dynamic calibrated microsimulation approach to assess the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on income distribution in Ireland. The method uses more timely external data than traditional income surveys, combining nowcasting methods and a household income generation model. The study found that the crisis had an equalizing effect on both gross and disposable incomes, despite the significant hardship experienced by many households. The research has been accepted for publication in Fiscal Studies.

Since January 2020, Elsevier has established a COVID-19 resource centre providing free information in English and Mandarin about the novel coronavirus. The resource centre, hosted on Elsevier Connect, allows all its COVID-19-related research to be freely available on PubMed Central and other publicly funded repositories. The company has also conducted a systematic review to evaluate the risk of virus spread due to surgical smoke during surgical procedures. While no study was found investigating SARS-CoV-2 or any other coronavirus, the theoretical risk of virus diffusion through surgical smoke cannot be excluded. Therefore, the adoption of protective strategies, including preoperative patient nasopharyngeal swab for COVID-19, is recommended.

This study examined the clinical characteristics of 45 patients diagnosed with COVID-19 at the Beijing You'an Hospital between January 28, 2020 and February 23, 2020. The average age of patients was 58 years, with 47% having underlying chronic diseases. The first symptoms were fever (80%), cough (51%), and expectoration (33%). Patients may also experience hepatic and renal injury and abnormal myocardial enzymes. Advanced age and chronic diseases were predictors for severe illness and increased mortality. Laboratory results regarding the NEU percentage, NLR, ALC, and C-reactive protein levels were significant in predicting critical disease or prognosis. The study found that COVID-19 may affect multiple organs and that glucocorticoid is effective in treating severe cases.

A study has described a hospital outbreak of influenza B virus (InfB) infection during the 2015/2016 season by combining clinical and epidemiological data with molecular methods. Twenty patients diagnosed with InfB from a hospital outbreak over a four-week period were included. All 20 cases of InfB were of subtype B/Yamagata, and 17 of 20 patients could be linked to each other by either shared room or shared ward. The study concluded that InfB may spread within an acute care hospital, and advanced molecular methods may facilitate assessment of the source and extent of the outbreak. Preventive measures include rapid diagnosis, early recognition of outbreak situations, simple rules for patient management and the use of regular infection control measures.

The Enterovirus A71 (EV-A71) infection, which can cause hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) and fatal meningoencephalitis, currently has no effective treatment due to a lack of understanding of the mechanism of neurological diseases. A study using SH-SY5Y human neuroblastoma cells found that the expression and activity of caspase-1, a protein involved in inflammation and cell death, were significantly increased after EV-A71 infection. This led to increased cell death, lysis, and DNA degradation, which could be alleviated by inhibiting caspase-1. This suggests that caspase-1-mediated pyroptosis, a type of programmed cell death, could be a new pathway for inflammatory cell death. The study used a strain of EV-A71 isolated from a child with HFMD and encephalitis.

Since January 2020, Elsevier has created a COVID-19 resource centre with free information on the virus. The company has granted permission for all its COVID-19-related research to be made available on publicly funded repositories, such as the WHO COVID database. The article discusses the use of contact-tracing apps to control the spread of the virus, but highlights potential issues with these apps. In April 2020, Diabetes Australia reported that some people with diabetes had experienced connection problems with their continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) apps after downloading the COVIDSafe app. The Department of Health of the Australian Government has advised users to stop using the COVIDSafe app if interference with medical devices arises. The issue is still under investigation.

A study involving 502 US residents aimed to understand the factors influencing anxiety and depression during the COVID-19 pandemic. The study found that personality traits such as extraversion, agreeableness, conscientiousness, and openness were negatively correlated with anxiety and depression, while neuroticism, health anxiety, and COVID-19 related distress were positively correlated. The study also found that health anxiety, COVID-19 anxiety, and the COVID-19 anxiety syndrome partially mediated the relationship between personality traits and anxiety and depression. These relationships were independent of age, gender, employment status, and risk status. The study concluded that understanding these factors could help manage psychological distress during the pandemic.

A study aimed to estimate the effective reproductive number (Rt) of COVID-19 during the first 10 days of the outbreak in seven Latin American countries with the highest incidence of cases as of March 23, 2020. The countries were compared with Spain and Italy due to their history with the virus. The study found that the median Rt for the first 10 days of the COVID-19 epidemic were 2.90 for Spain and 2.83 for Italy. Latin American Rt estimations were higher in Ecuador, Panama, and Brazil. The smallest one was observed in Peru. All Latin American countries had Rt greater than 2. The study suggests that interventions such as travel restrictions, educational institutions closure, social distancing, and intensified case surveillance should be adopted to prevent the collapse of the health systems.

Antibody-based microarrays are a new technology that could revolutionize proteomics. These microarrays can be printed with thousands of specific antibodies, which can then detect any bound analytes in a biological sample. The patterns generated can be converted into proteomic maps, revealing the composition of the proteome. This could provide new opportunities for biomarker discovery, drug target identification, and disease diagnostics. Two types of protein microarrays have been developed: functional protein microarrays and affinity microarrays. The latter has generated high expectations and could play a significant role in proteomics. The technology could also supplement current technologies like 2D gels and mass spectrometry.

A study investigating the mechanism and prognosis of occult hepatitis B virus (OBI) infection among healthy young adults found that despite neonatal vaccination, there is still a substantial risk of OBI in China. The study analyzed 1176 sera samples from healthy young people and found deletions in the pre-S, basal core promoter (BCP), core (C) and polymerase (P) regions of the HBV genome. These deletions play a direct or indirect role in OBI. A deletion mutation in the pre-S1 region was found to increase the risk of hepatocellular carcinoma. The prevalence of OBI was 0.79% among HBsAg-negative serum samples.

Since January 2020, Elsevier has created a COVID-19 resource centre with free information in English and Mandarin. The resource centre is hosted on Elsevier Connect, the company's public news and information website. Elsevier grants permission to make all its COVID-19-related research available on the COVID-19 resource centre, including in PubMed Central and other publicly funded repositories, such as the WHO COVID database. This permission is granted for free for as long as the COVID-19 resource centre remains active. The text also discusses a Serratia marcescens outbreak in an intensive care unit during the COVID-19 pandemic, suggesting that the conditions of the pandemic may have facilitated bacterial acquisition and cross-transmission between patients.

The article discusses the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on social movements. It notes that while lockdown measures initially halted mass protests, social movements have adapted and remained active during the pandemic. The article is divided into two sections, the first discussing the roles of grassroots movements and the second focusing on the struggle over the interpretation of the crisis. It highlights that while some see the pandemic as an opportunity to build a fairer world, others see it as a chance for reactionary, capitalist, and state actors to shape the world's future. The article also notes that some governments have used the pandemic to silence activists and control the press. Despite the focus on the pandemic, the article argues that social justice movements have remained active, focusing on protests, defending workers' rights, and other initiatives.

In an interview, Michael Berry discusses his journey in the field of Chinese studies, from his initial encounter with the Chinese language and translation to his scholarly work on "trauma" and "global China." He shares the challenges he faced as a translator and the evolving culture of translation of Chinese literature. Berry also talks about his experiences with oral history projects with filmmakers and writers, particularly his recent interviews with Hou Hsiao-hsien and Jia Zhangke. He also reflects on his early years as a jazz studies major and his transition into philosophy and literature.

The text is a review of the book "Ocean Travel and Cruising: A Cultural Analysis" by Arthur Asa Berger. The book discusses the economics of cruising, noting that cruise ships visit 1,800 ports worldwide, with the Caribbean and Bahamas being the most popular destinations. The author explains how cruise lines make money and save on costs, and how they attempt to appeal to a wide range of potential passengers. The book also explores the importance of semiotics in enticing prospective passengers, such as the use of fancy names for cabins and food, dress codes, and the names of cruise lines themselves.

A study of the genetic characteristics of Enterovirus D-68 (EV-D68) strains in Italy during an outbreak in 2016 found that the virus is a common cause of lower respiratory illness in children. The study, which involved 390 children, found that 22 were infected by EV-D68, most of whom were immunocompetent. Pneumonia was diagnosed in over half of the infected children. The strains identified in the study belonged to clade B3 and were most closely related to strains detected in Southern China in 2015 and in the US and the Netherlands in 2016. The study concluded that further research is needed to investigate whether some strains or lineages may have a higher affinity for the lower airway or central nervous system.

The text discusses a study conducted by various departments of the Consorci Hospital General Universitari in València, Spain, to evaluate the efficacy of tocilizumab and methylprednisolone in treating COVID-19. Tocilizumab, which blocks the IL-6 receptor, has been used to control the inflammatory response caused by SARS-CoV-2. However, some patients have shown persistent inflammatory response despite treatment with tocilizumab. Therefore, the researchers included methylprednisolone treatment in their local guidelines. The study aims to analyze the influence on survival of patients treated with tocilizumab where methylprednisolone was also added. The primary endpoint was in-hospital all-cause mortality. The results were analyzed using various statistical methods.

Researchers have found that the core antigen of the stork hepatitis B virus can effectively act as an adjuvant in hepatitis C virus-based DNA vaccines. This is significant as two billion people have been in contact with the human hepatitis B virus, which could interfere with its adjuvant effect. The stork antigen enhanced the priming of hepatitis C-specific responses in mice, and induced long-term functional memory T cell responses. This technology could potentially be expanded to other genetic vaccine antigens.

The article "Wildlife tourism in China: a review of the Chinese research literature" by Li Cong, David Newsome, Bihu Wu & Alastair M. Morrison, published in Current Issues in Tourism, provides a comprehensive review of research literature on wildlife tourism in China. The review reveals that wildlife tourism has gained significant attention in China recently, with a predominant focus on captive, semi-captive and tourism experiences in the wild, particularly involving the giant panda and bird-watching. The authors note that while there is a rising interest in wildlife tourism, the research is still in its early stages and there is potential for a more comprehensive and extended wildlife tourism research agenda.

This paper examines sexism in professional computer gaming, or esport, through a case study of a cheating accusation against a Korean woman, professional gamer Geguri. The study uses a textual analysis of the online discussion that followed the accusation, and situates the analysis within queer and feminist scholarship. The authors argue that surveillance mechanisms in gaming often uphold misogynistic narratives and are used differently for male and female gamers. However, in Geguri's case, her response to the accusations disrupted these norms. The paper also discusses the gender imbalances in esport, which reflect those in traditional sport and computer gaming culture.

The article discusses the potential use of recombinant technology to create a fertility-control vaccine for possums. The authors suggest that biological management of possum numbers, such as manipulating their physiological processes to reduce survival and breeding potential, could be a humane alternative to poisoning and trapping. The most publicly acceptable method of biological control is reducing or preventing possum breeding. The authors propose that fertility control by immunological means, or immunocontraception, could be a promising approach. This would involve immunising a possum against an essential component of the reproductive system, inducing an immune response that blocks the reproductive process and induces infertility.

Positive strand RNA virus populations are a collection of genetically different viruses that exist as viral quasispecies due to high mutation rates. This genomic diversity allows for adaptation to rapidly changing environments. However, this diversity also makes them susceptible to mutagens like ribavirin, which can increase sequence variation and potentially push the virus into 'error catastrophe'. Ribavirin, an antiviral nucleoside analog, is mutagenic to several RNA viruses and can cause lethal mutagenesis. Despite this, some viruses can develop resistance to ribavirin. These resistant viruses are less adaptable and more susceptible to other non-mutagenic antiviral drugs.

Newcastle disease (ND) is a highly contagious avian disease that causes significant economic losses in Pakistan's commercial poultry industry. Despite extensive vaccination programs, the disease remains endemic in commercial broiler and layer poultry farms. A study was conducted to identify the prevalent NDV strain responsible for disease outbreaks in commercial poultry farms in Punjab, Pakistan. The study found that six NDV isolates showed characteristics of velogenic strains of NDV. This is the first report demonstrating the presence of this strain. The disease, first identified in 1926, is considered a major infection of commercial poultry in Pakistan. It is believed that wild birds play a critical role in the spread of the virus.

Since January 2020, Elsevier has established a COVID-19 resource centre offering free information in English and Mandarin about the novel coronavirus. The resource centre is hosted on Elsevier Connect, the company's public news and information website. Elsevier has granted permission for all its COVID-19-related research available on the resource centre to be immediately accessible in PubMed Central and other publicly funded repositories, such as the WHO COVID database. This permission is granted for free for as long as the COVID-19 resource centre remains active. The text also discusses the issue of burnout among healthcare providers, particularly those caring for pediatric patients with complex diseases. A pilot study at Cincinnati Children’s Hospital Medical Center found that mindfulness-based cognitive therapy sessions improved empathy, stress, anxiety, and resilience among providers.

Despite advancements in colorectal cancer (CRC) treatment, cure rates for metastatic CRC have not improved due to high resistance rates to the common treatment regime, FOLFOX. This treatment also leads to significant toxicity, cost, and inconvenience for patients. Drug resistance is linked to CRC stem cells, which are associated with the epidermal-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT) pathway. A new small molecule, NSC30049 (7a), has been identified that is effective alone and in combination with 5-FU in inhibiting the growth of CRC cells, including FOLFOX-resistant and CRC stem cells. A stable and effective analog of 7a, ASR352 (7b), has been identified that also inhibits the growth of CRC cells and reduces the sphere formation capacity of CRC stem cells. The study suggests that 7b could be developed as a therapeutic agent for metastatic CRC.
You didn't provide any text to summarize. Please provide the text you want summarized.

The text discusses the types of viruses found in stools, which are either cultivable (like enteroviruses and certain adenoviruses) or non-cultivable (like rotaviruses, Norwalk, calicivirus, astrovirus, SRSV and SRV). Non-cultivable viruses have been linked to many cases of diarrhea and can cause outbreaks. Diagnostic methods include electron microscopy and specific methods like latex agglutination and enzyme immunoassays. False positive and negative results can occur. In an outbreak, electron microscopic examinations are essential. In individual cases, a commercial kit can be used to diagnose rotavirus and possibly adenovirus 40 and 41. Some stools may contain more than one potentially pathogenic virus.

The text suggests that a universal repeated testing strategy could be an effective alternative to lockdowns in controlling the spread of COVID-19. The authors recommend weekly testing of the entire population of a city, with strict household quarantine after a positive test. The quarantine would end when all residents of the household test negative. The testing program should be assessed for feasibility in cities with 200,000-300,000 people. If successful, this strategy could save hundreds of thousands of lives, prevent overloading of intensive care units, and mitigate the adverse effects of lockdown on mental health and unemployment.

The paper reviews the use of hypochlorous acid (HOCl) as an effective, inexpensive, and non-toxic disinfectant against the COVID-19 virus in office settings. The review includes evidence of the solution's use in various locations and industries outside of oral-maxillofacial clinics. The results suggest that HOCl can be used with high predictability for disinfecting against COVID-19. The virus, which causes severe acute respiratory syndrome, is transmissible through touch or aerosol spreading and can remain on various surfaces for hours to days, necessitating effective disinfection methods.

Researchers are proposing a new strategy to combat SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19. The strategy involves three components: Specificity, Remedy, and a Conveyor. Specificity involves using ACE2 receptors in conveyor cells to trick the virus. The Remedy component proposes using a cost-effective artificial surfactant system to treat pulmonary complications, as a lack of pulmonary surfactants can cause severe acute respiratory distress syndrome. The Conveyor component suggests using red blood cells to deliver the artificial surfactant and ACE2 receptors to the target. This strategy aims to provide a new direction in the fight against SARS-CoV-2.

The text presents various approaches to model the evolution of the COVID-19 epidemic in Argentina, particularly in Buenos Aires and its metropolitan area. The models range from simple homogeneous ones to complex inhomogeneous models that incorporate mobility estimates from cell phone location data. The models are capable of producing forecasts consistent with the official number of cases with minimal parameter fitting and fine-tuning. The authors discuss the strengths and limitations of these models and caution future modeling efforts to be careful in interpreting long-term forecasts and adopting non-pharmaceutical interventions. Elsevier has created a COVID-19 resource centre with free information and has granted permission for unrestricted research re-use and analyses of its COVID-19-related research.

Since January 2020, Elsevier has established a COVID-19 resource centre providing free information in English and Mandarin about the novel coronavirus. The resource centre is hosted on Elsevier Connect, the company's public news and information website. Elsevier has granted permission for all its COVID-19-related research available on the resource centre to be immediately accessible in PubMed Central and other publicly funded repositories, such as the WHO COVID database. This permission is granted for free and will last as long as the COVID-19 resource centre remains active. The text also discusses a case of an African American patient with COVID-19, raising questions about the potential increased risk of kidney disease in people of African descent with a high-risk APOL1 genotype in the context of COVID-19.

COVIDep is a web-based platform that provides immune target recommendations for the development of a SARS-CoV-2 vaccine. The platform pools together publicly-available genetic data for SARS-CoV-2 and epitope data for SARS-CoV to identify potential immune targets. The platform is user-friendly, flexible, and updated regularly with new data. It uses the genetic similarities between SARS-CoV-2 and SARS-CoV, along with known immune targets for SARS-CoV, to recommend vaccine targets. The use of SARS-CoV immunological data to inform vaccine targets for SARS-CoV-2 is supported by experimental results.

The study aimed to understand the epidemiology of COVID-19 in Jodhpur, India, by estimating the serial interval and basic reproduction number (R0) to predict the epidemic size for the next month. Contact tracing was used to obtain serial intervals and R0 values. The median serial interval was estimated at 5.98 days, and the overall R0 value in the first 30 days of the outbreak was 1.64, which decreased to 1.07. The projected COVID-19 case-load over the next month was 1881 individuals. A reduction of R0 from 1.17 to 1.085 could result in a 23% reduction in the projected epidemic size. Aggressive testing, contact-tracing, and isolation resulted in a reduction of R0. Strengthening control measures could substantially reduce the COVID-19 epidemic size.

A study on sheep exposed to the steroid betamethasone before birth found no difference in the expression of angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) or ACE2 proteins in the kidney cortex of either gender. However, there was a significant gender-related difference in ACE2 protein expression, with male sheep showing a 54% reduction. This could contribute to previously observed gender differences in sodium handling and hypertension in offspring exposed to betamethasone.

The immune systems of animals that hunt and scavenge, such as spotted hyenas, are believed to have evolved to survive exposure to a wide range of pathogens. Spotted hyenas, which descended from carrion-feeding ancestors, have shown resistance to diseases like anthrax and rabies that have decimated other carnivore populations. Researchers have been studying the immune function of spotted hyenas, using domestic cats as a comparison due to their close phylogenetic relationship. They have found similarities in the immunoglobulins of both species, and have been able to monitor the hyena's antibody response to immunization. This research will help in understanding pathogen exposure and immune function in hyenas and other similar species.

The study aimed to evaluate the expression of certain cell surface antigens in lung samples from children who died from severe acute respiratory infections. The study found that TCD8+ lymphocytes play a significant role in the response to viral pneumonia, while CD14+ cell numbers are often reduced in cases of adenovirus infection. The study also found a predominance of CD74+ cells in cases of interstitial pneumonitis. The findings suggest that an individual's cellular response plays a critical role in recovery from infections.

The study aimed to determine if a primary infection of porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome (PRRS) virus influences the clinical outcome of experimentally induced classical swine fever (CSF) in young pigs. Fifteen 6-week-old crossbred weaners were divided into three groups and inoculated with PRRS virus, CSF virus, or both. The PRRS virus infected weaners developed mild symptoms and recovered, while those inoculated with CSF virus showed severe clinical signs. The group inoculated with both viruses had a slightly different clinical course. The findings cast doubt on the relevance of PRRS virus infection significantly potentiating the clinical outcome of CSF in young pigs.

The COVID-19 lockdown has led to a significant reduction in global economic activity and associated air pollution levels, particularly from land transportation. Data from over 10,000 air quality stations across 34 countries was used to study the impact on levels of nitrogen dioxide, ozone and particulate matter smaller than 2.5 μm in diameter (PM2.5). The study estimates that the lockdown resulted in 49,900 excess deaths and 89,000 pediatric asthma emergency room visits being avoided. In China and India alone, the PM2.5-related avoided excess mortality was 19,600 and 30,500 respectively. The findings highlight the potential health benefits of reducing air pollutant emissions from economic activities, primarily through finding alternative transportation solutions.

Neuroactive steroids are endogenous neuromodulators that alter neuronal excitability by binding to membrane receptors. They can be synthesized in the brain from cholesterol, or can reach the brain from peripheral steroidogenic organs, such as adrenals and gonads, and are locally metabolized. The synthesis of neuroactive steroids requires the translocation of cholesterol across the mitochondrial membrane, which occurs through a molecular complex. In the mitochondria, cholesterol is converted to pregnenolone, which is further metabolized into different neuroactive steroids. The most potent neuroactive steroids are the progesterone metabolite and the deoxycorticosterone metabolite, which enhance GABAA receptor mediated neurotransmission and produce inhibitory neurobehavioral effects.

The text discusses the synthesis and evaluation of N-terminal peptides that correspond to the Son interface of the HIV-1 protease. These peptides have been evaluated as inhibitors of HIV-1 protease activity. The virally encoded protease has become a major target for antiviral agents due to its crucial role in the maturation of HIV. The structure of the HIV-1 protease has been determined by X-ray crystallography and is composed of 99 amino acid residues. The dimeric nature of the HIV-1 protease offers a new mode of enzyme inhibition. Blocking the assembly of the HIV-1 protease homodimer or disrupting the dimeric interface could be a unique way of inhibiting protease activity. The study also investigates the main areas of monomer overlap in HIV-1 protease for potential dimerization inhibition.

The text discusses the challenges in accurately determining the age of bruises based on color alone, a common practice in child abuse cases. It references a review by Maguire and colleagues, which found little scientific basis for this method after reviewing 6831 papers and finding only three that met their strict criteria. The review also found variation in human color discrimination. These findings support the need for caution when testifying in court about the age of a bruise. The text also mentions a study by Bariciak et al, which found that physicians' estimates of bruise ages are often inaccurate. The authors emphasize the need for more rigorous research and a comprehensive clinical and developmental history, physical assessment, and analysis of relevant data when determining child abuse.

The text is an introduction to an article about the experiences of young medical residents in Belgium during the COVID-19 pandemic. The authors, who are affiliated with the University of Antwerp and AZ Monica Deurne/Antwerp, discuss the rapid changes in their work environment and the challenges they faced as the virus spread. They describe how hospitals quickly transformed to accommodate COVID-19 patients, with non-urgent procedures postponed and increased ICU capacity. The authors also note the implementation of public health measures such as social distancing and quarantine.

Elsevier has created a COVID-19 resource centre with free information in English and Mandarin. The centre is hosted on Elsevier Connect, the company's public news and information website. Elsevier has granted permission to make all its COVID-19-related research available on the resource centre, including in PubMed Central and other publicly funded repositories, such as the WHO COVID database. This permission is granted for free for as long as the COVID-19 resource centre remains active. The text also discusses the challenges and modifications made to perform emergency tracheostomies during the COVID-19 pandemic in a head and neck surgical oncology unit in India.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a significant increase in psychological and mental health disorders, according to a study conducted in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KPK), Pakistan. Due to lockdown and mobility restrictions, the data was collected through an online survey distributed via social media and other online platforms. A total of 501 respondents participated in the survey. The study was made available for free on Elsevier's COVID-19 resource centre for unrestricted research use and analysis.

The cellular uptake of coronaviruses, including SARS-CoV-2, the virus causing COVID-19, is thought to involve angiotensin-converting enzyme-2 (ACE2) and possibly integrins, proteins that modulate cell behavior. Specifically, integrin αvβ3 has been implicated in the uptake of a model porcine enteric α-coronavirus. The thyroid hormone analogue, L-thyroxine (T4), which binds to integrin αvβ3, could potentially influence the uptake of coronaviruses by target cells. If this is the case, other thyroid hormone analogues could be used to block the virus-relevant actions of T4 at integrin αvβ3 and possibly restrict virus uptake. This could provide a potential therapeutic intervention for COVID-19.

A study has found that the COVID-19 lockdown significantly worsened blood glucose control in individuals with type 1 diabetes (T1D). The study, which involved 50 T1D patients, found that time in range (TIR) significantly decreased, while mean glucose levels and estimated HbA1c increased from pre- to lockdown period. However, overall glucose control significantly improved when restrictions ended. The study also found that lockdown-associated work loss/suspension was a major determinant of impaired TIR. The researchers concluded that work instability and related issues were the main determinant of impaired glucose variability in this population.

Recent studies have shown that the angiotensin-converting enzyme-II (ACE2) plays a key role in the entry of SARS-CoV-2 into host cells. The severity of the disease and the replication rate of SARS-CoV is controlled by the binding affinity of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) with ACE2. Researchers have studied how mutations in the RBD affect its interaction with ACE2, revealing that these mutations can lead to a loss of important intermolecular bonds and other non-bonded contacts. This information could be crucial in the development of new drugs to combat SARS-CoV-2. The virus, which originated in Wuhan, South China, has spread globally, infecting over 10.5 million people and causing over 511,851 deaths.

The chapter discusses various experimental methods to characterize the fuzziness of complexes made of the C-terminal domain of the nucleoprotein (NTAIL) from three paramyxoviruses and the C-terminal X domain (XD) of the homologous phosphoprotein. The NTAIL–XD complexes show a significant amount of conformational heterogeneity, and NTAIL is highly malleable, suggesting its plasticity and fuzziness play a role in the coordination and regulation of the NTAIL interaction network. The chapter also discusses the use of size-exclusion chromatography (SEC) and SEC coupled to multiple angle laser light scattering (SEC-MALLS) to document lack of significant compaction upon complex formation. However, these methods have limitations, including the ability to document complex formation.

The text discusses a study that used machine learning to predict the spread and duration of COVID-19 cases in India. The study used the Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average Model (ARIMA) and three regression techniques: Support Vector Regression, Neural Network, and Linear Regression. The results indicated that the disease could be accurately predicted and suggested that it could be transmitted through water and air. The study concluded that preventive measures such as social distancing, mask-wearing, and staying at home could effectively manage the spread of the virus and reduce the death rate.

Since January 2020, Elsevier has created a COVID-19 resource centre with free information on the novel coronavirus in English and Mandarin. The resource centre is hosted on Elsevier Connect, the company's public news and information website. Elsevier has granted permission to make all its COVID-19-related research available on the resource centre, including in PubMed Central and other publicly funded repositories, such as the WHO COVID database. This permission is granted for free for as long as the COVID-19 resource centre remains active.

The text discusses the development of complex diseases, which are influenced by genetic susceptibility factors, environmental exposure factors, and their potential interactions. Chatterjee and Caroll (2005) developed a method for analyzing case-control studies, assuming independence of genetic and environmental effects. This method was extended by Spinka et al (2005) to include studies with missing information. The authors further extend this approach to situations where environmental exposures are measured with error. They propose using a pseudo-likelihood and an associated EM algorithm for parameter estimation. They also discuss the complications of inferences with measurement error corrections. The performance of the proposed method is illustrated with simulation studies. Finally, the method is applied to a case-control study on the association between calcium intake and the risk of colorectal adenoma.

The study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of peptide-coated vascular grafts in sheep. The grafts were coated with a P15 cell-binding peptide and implanted in two sheep. The results showed a significant difference in intimal thickness between the coated and uncoated grafts, with the coated samples being three times thinner. The endothelial cell lining was also thicker and more uniform in the coated grafts. The study concluded that P15-coated grafts had less intimal tissue in-growth and improved cell adhesion, proliferation, and migration compared to uncoated grafts. This could potentially improve vascular access in end-stage renal disease patients, reducing hospitalizations and costs.

Scientists have found a potential way to control plant reovirus infection in crops. They introduced an RNA interference construct against the P9-1-encoding gene of the Rice black streaked dwarf virus, which accumulates in viroplasms, the sites of viral replication. The resulting transgenic plants produced short interfering RNAs specific to the construct. All offspring of these plants were resistant to the virus, suggesting that interfering with the expression of a viroplasm component protein could be an effective way to control plant reovirus infection.

Prostate cancer is a significant public health issue and a leading cause of cancer-related illness and death in the United States, despite a decline in annual prostate cancer-specific mortality rates over the past decade. The reasons for this decline are unclear, but may be due to a combination of factors. This review will examine recent developments and summarize advances in prostate cancer treatment, based on the current understanding of prostate cancer biology. The review will focus on clinical studies in advanced prostate cancer therapeutics over the past 5 to 10 years, and will also include new hormonal agents targeting the androgen receptor currently in development for the treatment of advanced prostate cancer.

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the World Health Organization (WHO) recommend consulting their guidelines before using certain antiviral agents clinically, including for infections by novel strains of influenza-like avian H5N1. A triple drug regimen (amantadine, ribavirin, oseltamivir) is currently being studied for influenza A infections, including those resistant to adamantane. These agents are 70–90% effective in preventing infection and reducing fever and symptoms duration when used for treatment. However, widespread resistance to all M2 inhibitors has been documented in circulating influenza A strains. Side effects of these drugs include minor central nervous system complaints and gastrointestinal upset. Care should be taken when co-administering these agents with other drugs due to potential interactions. Resistance to these agents can emerge within 2–4 days after the start of therapy in up to 30% of patients infected with initially susceptible strains.

The Middle Eastern respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) emerged in 2012 and has a high mortality rate due to severe lung disease. The receptor for MERS-CoV is Dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), a type II transmembrane ectopeptidase. A study found that DPP4 was rarely detected in the surface epithelium from the nasal cavity to conducting airways, but was found in a subset of mononuclear leukocytes and in serous cells of submucosal glands. It was also found in type I and II cells and alveolar macrophages in the parenchyma. Patients with chronic lung disease, such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and cystic fibrosis, exhibited increased DPP4 immunostaining in alveolar epithelia and alveolar macrophages. This suggests that preexisting pulmonary disease could increase MERS-CoV receptor abundance and predispose individuals to MERS morbidity and mortality.
